training_organizations.name: Rhode Island DCYF Training School (Learning Partnership with RIC)
training_organizations.description: Rhode Island’s Department of Children, Youth & Families operates a Training School for its CPS workforce in partnership with Rhode Island College. New child protective investigators and family services staff train through this program, learning RI’s policies, the Signs of Safety practice model adopted by DCYF, and skills for engaging families. The partnership with RIC helps incorporate academic expertise and provides credit-bearing opportunities for staff’s professional growth.

training_organizations.name: Family Service of Rhode Island
training_organizations.description: A nonprofit agency that delivers a variety of services complementing DCYF’s work. Family Service of RI provides family preservation and reunification programs, therapeutic visitation for parents and children, and runs a Children’s Advocacy Center for abuse victims. DCYF often refers families to this organization for counseling, parenting support, and supervised visitation, leveraging the NGO’s resources to help meet court-ordered service goals so children can safely remain home or return home.

training_organizations.name: Adoption Rhode Island
training_organizations.description: A nonprofit organization dedicated to finding adoptive families for children in state foster care and supporting those youth. Adoption Rhode Island works closely with DCYF to recruit potential adoptive parents, host matching events, and prepare older foster youth for adoption. They also provide post-adoption support services. This partnership improves permanency outcomes in Rhode Island by focusing attention and resources on the children who wait the longest for a family.

policies.TribalFoster: No, Tribes within state do not provide foster care
policies.DefAge_Specify: Under age 18 and up to 21 if in the care of the agency
policies.Def_OtherSpecify: Other abuse or neglect including any action or lack of action which results in harm or potential harm to the physical, mental health, behavioral health or welfare of the child and which is not covered by the other allegations
policies.FatalitiesReview: Yes, reviews are required for all or some cases
policies.EquityStaff_Specify: A race equity team made up of staff, senior leadership, members of the agency's Diversity Advisory Committee (DAC), and external partners
policies.NearFatalitiesReview: Yes, reviews are required for all or some cases
policies.ConsentDecree_Specify: Sam and Tony M. vs. Carcieri; Office of the Child Advocate vs. Rossi; Andrew C. vs. Raimondo; Office of the Child Advocate vs. Lindgren
policies.AntiDiscrim_OtherSpecify: Association with an individual or group who has or is perceived to have one or more of such characteristics
policies.DefAge_VaryByTypeSpecify: A child includes persons up to age 21 if either 1) involved with the department and a victim of sex trafficking or is at risk of being a victim of sex trafficking or 2) if the youth is residing in foster or institutional care or is in department custody
policies.EquityStaff_OtherSpecify: The race equity team develops approaches to address disproportionalities and disparate outcomes across all areas of child welfare.; Each service division developed a set of strategies to address foundational issues that affect inequity; DCYF's racial equity work includes an effort to enhance prevention efforts to mitigate factors that place families at risk of DCYF involvement, and eliminate racial and ethnic disproportionality in the child welfare system
policies.DefPerp_VaryByTypeSpecify: The perpetrator of sexual abuse of a child can be another child; Any person can be a perpetrator of sex trafficking
policies.InvestQual_TrainingSpecify: New Worker Training consists of 26-week core curriculum courses on DCYF procedure and protocols, comprehensive assessment, service planning, safety, risk, and protective capacity, family engagement, and building health engagement ; All staff are required to complete 20 hours of training annually
policies.InvestQual_ExperienceSpecify: 2-3 years of full-time employment in a private or public agency in the field of human services casework with experience assessing and working with families and providing direct services in the community related to child welfare, child safety and child well-being
policies.ScreenerQual_TrainingSpecify: New Worker Training consists of 26-week core curriculum courses on DCYF procedure and protocols, comprehensive assessment, service planning, safety, risk, and protective capacity, family engagement, and building health engagement; All staff are required to complete 20 hours of training annually
policies.AntiDiscrim_Staff_VarySpecify: (1) Age, race, disability, religion, national origin, poverty, color, ancestry, political beliefs or affiliations, and association with an individual or group who has or is perceived to have one or more of such characteristics are specified for staff from child welfare agency; (2) Gender identity or expression and sexual orientation are specified for staff from child welfare agency, interns, and volunteers
policies.CaseManagerQual_ExperienceSpec: 2 years of experience in the field of family and children services
policies.InvestReq_MedEvalCases_Specify: Child fatalities; Physical abuse; Sexual abuse; Reports meeting investigation criteria for serious, critical injury, child near fatality or child fatality
policies.ScreenerQual_ExperienceSpecify: 2-3 years of full-time employment in a private or public agency in the field of human services casework with experience assessing and working with families and providing direct services in the community related to child welfare, child safety and child well-being
policies.AltResp_EligibilityMaltreatment: All types of maltreatment are eligible
policies.CaseManagerQual_TrainingSpecify: New Worker Training consists of 26-week core curriculum courses on DCYF procedure and protocols, comprehensive assessment, service planning, safety, risk, and protective capacity, family engagement, and building health engagement; All staff are required to complete 20 hours of training annually
policies.ExtFosterCare_Reentry_OtherSpec: Same criteria as remaining in extended foster care
policies.AltResp_Eligibility_OtherSpecify: Risk areas and vulnerability factors that warrant a family assessment response include the following: (1) Children age 6 and younger, (2) Caretaker or child's emotional, physical, or developmental condition, (3) Circumstances indicating that the caregiver's protective capacity might be compromised, (4) Prior report within a 12-month period involving a family with a child age 6 or younger, or with two or more children, (5) One or more prior reports received about a family within a three-month period, (6) Prior indicated investigation or removal within the past 12 months, (7) Any other risk factors that might compromise the well-being of the child, (8) Whether the report was called in by a professional mandated reporter In-home services are available from contracted community providers. The state's case managers who are assigned to children manage the child's service plan regardless of the placement (foster care, congregate care, home placement, etc.).
